title: 113_s2664
content: The Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization Act of 2014, also known as the IPAWS Modernization Act, amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to enhance the Integrated Public Alert and Warning System. The Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization Act of 2014 aims to modernize the public alert and warning system to provide timely warnings for natural disasters, terrorism, and other threats to public safety. The Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization Act of 2014 aims to disseminate timely warnings and homeland security information for natural disasters, terrorism, and other threats to public safety. The Administrator is required to establish common alerting and warning protocols, adapt communications based on location and risks, and provide equivalent information in the public alert and warning system. The Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization Act of 2014 requires the system to alert individuals with disabilities, access and functional needs, and limited-English proficiency. Training, tests, and exercises are conducted to ensure the system's effectiveness, including incorporating it into other training programs and establishing a comprehensive training program for government officials. The Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization Act of 2014 mandates conducting periodic nationwide tests of the public alert and warning system, ensuring its resilience against external attacks, and conducting public education efforts to promote understanding and usage of the system. Collaboration with private sector entities and government agencies is also required. The public alert and warning system must collaborate with private sector entities and government agencies, including Regional Administrators and emergency response providers. It should incorporate multiple communication technologies, adapt to future technologies, and provide alerts to the largest portion of the population. Coordination with the Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Subcommittee is also required. The public alert and warning system aims to provide alerts to a wide range of individuals, including tourists, those with disabilities, and limited-English proficiency. It also seeks to improve alert reception in remote areas, promote partnerships for community preparedness, use redundant alert mechanisms, and prioritize individual privacy protection. The public alert and warning system is designed to transmit messages related to natural disasters, acts of terrorism, or other man-made disasters. Consumer opt-out rights are protected under the SAFE Port Act. The Administrator is required to provide performance reports on the system's implementation and goals annually. The public alert and warning system's performance, technology used, measures for individuals with disabilities, challenges, and plans to address them are reported annually by the Agency. The Administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency is required to report annually on the public alert and warning system's performance, technology, challenges, necessary improvements, and a comparison with established performance goals to Congress. Additionally, an Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Subcommittee is to be established within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Emergency Management Agency will establish an Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Subcommittee with specific members including the Deputy Administrator for Protection and National Preparedness, the Chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, and the Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Subcommittee will include key members such as the Deputy Administrator for Protection and National Preparedness, the Chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, and the Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, among others appointed by the Administrator. The Subcommittee will be appointed by the Administrator after the enactment of this Act and will include representatives from State and local governments, emergency management agencies, emergency response providers, federally recognized Indian tribes, national Indian organizations, and individuals with technical expertise in communications services and technology. The Subcommittee appointed by the Administrator will include representatives from various industries such as vendors, developers, manufacturers, service bureaus, broadcasting, cellular, cable, and satellite industries, as well as national organizations representing individuals with disabilities and the elderly. The Subcommittee appointed by the Administrator will include representatives from various industries and organizations representing individuals with disabilities, the elderly, consumer or privacy advocates, and individuals with limited-English proficiency. The Deputy Administrator for Protection and National Preparedness of the Federal Emergency Management Agency will serve as the Chairperson of the Subcommittee, with the initial meeting scheduled to take place within 120 days. The Subcommittee, appointed by the Administrator, will meet at least annually after the initial meeting within 120 days of enactment. They will consult with nonmembers to explore new technologies for the public alert and warning system. The Subcommittee appointed by the Administrator will develop recommendations for an integrated public alert and warning system, considering common protocols, standards, and procedures. The system should have the capability to adapt communications based on location, risks, and personal factors. The integrated public alert and warning system should adapt communications based on location, risks, and personal preferences. It must alert individuals with disabilities and limited-English proficiency, incorporate multiple communication technologies, and be designed to adapt to future technologies for communicating with the public effectively. The integrated public alert and warning system aims to reach the largest affected population, including visitors and tourists, enhance community partnerships for preparedness, and provide redundant alert mechanisms for widespread communication. The Subcommittee must submit a report to the National Advisory Council within 1 year of the Act's enactment, containing recommendations for approval. If approved, the Council will then submit the report to relevant agencies and the Committee on Homeland Security. The Subcommittee established by the Act must report to the National Advisory Council within 1 year, with recommendations for approval. The Subcommittee will terminate within 3 years of the Act's enactment. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2015, 2016, and 2017. No impact on existing obligations of relevant entities.
